passages.text: We consider India telcos market to be in a sweet spot given benign competition, stable regulations, multiple growth levers (like home broadband uptake) & upside optionality from DC/AL. We find Bharti & Jio best placed in the space and maintain Buy on Bharti and RIL (parent- co of Jio). We consider potential mobile tariff hike (est. in 1HCY26) to be a catalyst for the sector. At our POs, Jio trades at FY27E EBITDA of 12.2X vs Bharti at 13.3X. The likely discount for Jio vs. Bharti is due to better margins and FCF for Bharti vs Jio. As FCF of Jio starts to improve, we expect the valuation gap to narrow.

We consider both Bharti & Jio well placed to gain market share at the expense of VIL. As an incumbent, we est. Bharti to have higher proportion of premium subscribers and Jio being a relatively new entrant has higher mix of price sensitive users. Hence, we believe that Bharti benefited more than Jio in last few tariff hikes (better ARPU flow though as it faced less down trading risks). Going ahead, with most SIM consolidation behind, we expect Jio to show similar tariff flow- through in ARPU like Bharti.

Jio has first mover advantage on FWA service driven by 1) Faster & wider rollout of SA 5G allowing it to network slicing; 2) better fiber deployment and is leveraging UBR; 3) it has both low band and high- band spectrums helping it provide both capacity & coverage; 4) Advantage in bundling content with good content owned by sister company. Bharti is also investing in FWA with most of incremental capex towards home broadband.

Bharti is the dominant incumbent in the enterprise space. The digital business of Bharti enterprise (IoT, Cloud, CPaaS etc) is growing at c.23%. Bharti has exited the low margin wholesale business, and its core connectivity business (though has strong margins) is growing at 4- 5% annually. Jio as a challenger is gradually scaling- up in the enterprise space. Jio is tapping into bundled connectivity, security & Wi- Fi stack. Per mgmt, Jio is working with automotive companies, quick commerce dark stores, has won good government tenders and is gaining wallet share in BFSI space.

Both Bharti & Jio are keen to scale up DCs & offer Al services to enterprises & users. Given current limited visibility on any Al- led earnings contribution, we consider Al as an optionality for both. Jio: The current datacenter assets are not a part of Jio but on RIL's balance sheet. Jio can still provide a full stack Al offering using GPU- as- a- service model. Bharti's DC Nx is one of India's top DC with 14 large hyperscale DCs and 120+ edge DCs. Similar to Jio, Bharti is also building on Al tools & solutions.
Equity India Telecom Services
Deep dive on Jio: Connectivity momentum steady; Digital biz has potential to surprise

With VIL struggling to invest capex in its network, we find Bharti and Jio well placed to continue to gain market share. Regulations in the sector remain stable with government keen to aid sector to ensure it remains a 3- player market.

Competition stable; Jio/Bharti gaining share: We consider India cellular market to be a 2.5 telco- operator market with Jio and Bharti being dominant operators gaining market share at the expense of the struggling \(3^{\text{rd}}\) telco Vodafone Idea (VIL). As Bharti is an incumbent operator, it has a higher proportion of premium end users and Jio being a relatively new entrant has higher proportion of price sensitive users, in our view. Indeed, in the last 3 tariff hikes, we saw ARPU improvement/uptake slightly better for Bharti when compared to Jio. We expect VIL to continue to lose market share going ahead and expect Bharti and Jio to continue to gain share.

Tariff adjustments seen; but headline tariff hike likely in CY26: Recently, both Bharti and Jio removed their entry level offering of 1 GB/day, making 1.5 GB/day as the new entry option. Even Jio's Rs 799 prepaid plan is not available on its app. We believe telcos are experimenting to see if they could nudge the users to pay more. We think, depending on the user response, telcos may either reverse these plans or continue to nudge users more. Our channel checks indicate that these plans are available in offline channels (only removed in online channels), allowing them to scale back if needed.
Exhibit 6: Revenue market share basis TRAI AGR data Calculated as AGR divided by subscriber base

We see room for 1 to 2 more rounds of tariff hikes in coming years before ARPU grows largely in- line with inflation. We expect the next tariff hike to be in 1HCY26 and in the range of 10- 14%. With most of the SIM consolidation largely behind, we expect both Jio and Bharti to equally benefit from any incremental tariff hikes. Even without tariff hikes, we see ARPU to inch up as telcos continue to push users to move from prepaid to postpaid, featurephone to smartphone and improve international roaming penetration.

Margins to improve; capex should normalize: We expect the continued gradual improvement in cellular margins for telcos led by operational leverage benefits & focus on cost control despite estimated increase in network opex. With peak coverage capex for 5G behind, we don't expect capex to materially increase from these levels for Bharti & Jio. Incremental spend by telcos is largely on FWA, selective fiber investments & 5G coverage expansion. Upside risks remain if capacity needs for 5G increase (particularly for Bharti).

Both Bharti and Jio are seeing good traction in home broadband (both fixed broadband and fixed wireless access) offerings. Jio currently has \(85\%\) of total FY25 industry new additions mainly led by its first mover advantage in FWA.

Accelerated growth in home broadband: Historically home broadband subs growth has been soft in India mainly led by higher price points and cannibalization from cellular services. But post Covid, we are seeing demand for home broadband services increased led by 1) work from home, 2) study from home and 3) entertainment (e.g. OTTs like Netflix) from home. Furthermore, competition from new entrant Jio also led to lower price points, attracting more users. Going ahead, we expect \(20\% +\) CAGR revenue growth in home broadband with Bharti and Jio gaining share given investments in fiber and bundling content alongside.
Exhibit 15: Home Broadband industry subs growth for last decade Inflxion point for uptake around Covid (FY21)
Source: BofA Global Research, TRAI
Exhibit 16: Penetration of home broadband as \(\%\) of households India at \(15\%\) penetration near the bottom amongst regional peers
Source: BofA Global Research, TRAI, ITU

FWA traction faster, Jio has dominant share currently: Despite demand for home broadband, the pace of addition of users on the fixed broadband front is slow. This is because, the RWA permissions, cable deployment etc takes time. FWA allows telcos to circumvent these issues & meet the increasing demand. This is because high- speed 5G service gives similar speeds as fixed broadband without any deployment issues. We hence believe FWA would be able to expand the TAM for home broadband. We believe FWA potential market size could be \(100\mathrm{nm + }\) homes vs c. 30- 40nm TAM of fixed broadband. Jio & Bharti are the only two telcos who are offering FWA services in India.

Jio has first mover advantage on FWA service. This is driven by 1) Faster rollout of Standalone 5G on a much larger scale (beyond top 1,000 cities) and ability to do network slicing (allowing customized network services); 2) has better fiber deployment versus peers and is leveraging UBR technology; 3) it has both low band (700 MHz) and high- band spectrum (26 GHz) helping it provide both capacity and coverage; 4) Advantage in bundling content as content like IPL, Disney, Viacom 18 is owned by sister company. As Jio has largely made 5G its investments, we estimate the EBITDA margins on the FWA service to be \(50\% +\) . While Bharti has been a relative late entrant, it is increasing its capex investments to tap the market. Bharti mgmt intends to get to a quarterly run rate of 2.5mn home passes up from 1.6mn.
Exhibit 17: 5G FWA subs base comparison (mn)  Jio has 6mn+FWA subs as of Jun'25 vs 1.7mn for Bharti
Exhibit 18: Monthly 5G FWA net adds (mn)  Monthly adds run-rate on a YTD basis

Approach similar by Jio & Bharti: In our view, both Jio & Bharti have a similar approach towards home broadband. The preference is to acquire the user on fixed broadband. FWA is mainly offered in areas where there is no fixed broadband - especially beyond the top 50 cities. Our checks indicate that between Jio & Bharti, Jio is currently leveraging UBR technology with point-to-multi-point radios. The key advantages of deploying UBR include: 1) Dynamically adjust between uplink and downlink capacity. This especially helps FWA as downloads are higher; 2) Risks of running out of capacity is not there as UBR has sufficient capacity; 3) It is economical cost-wise is UBR band is an unlicensed one. As per Jio, many of its FWA users are using UBR technology now and get c.1 Gbps plus speeds. Infact, we think UBR should help Jio in getting close to its ambitious \(100+\) mn households for home broadband target in cost effective manner.

In enterprise, part of connectivity market (low margin wholesale one) is seeing pricing erosion & another part (new age biz like cybersecurity, IoT & cloud biz) is seeing strong growth. Connectivity remains stable for incumbents. SMB adoption may help the expand market, with challengers like Jio benefitting from this.

The top two telcos who dominate the enterprise market are Tata Communications/Tele services and Bharti - both have distinct positioning. Experts indicate that Tatas are strong with Indian branches of international companies and Bharti's strong hold is connectivity offerings with larger Indian enterprises as well as with government contracts. Since its launch in 2017, Jio was focusing mainly on cellular and home broadband services. With both these services now scaled well, Jio has now started to focus on the enterprise business as the next growth driver. As a new entrant, we expect Jio's traction to be gradual. Initial wins are likely with government tenders & offering services which incumbents don't offer (like connectivity in Tier 2/3 cities where Jio has deeper fiber penetration or based on SA 5G offering).

Majority of the enterprise market size is driven by the top 5K corporate customers and the government contracts. However the SMBs in India are not serviced by the telcos. This is because size of market is not clear given the price sensitive nature of this segment. Jio has indicated that it has intentions to service this market. Jio would ideally bundle its FWA offering with cloud & other services like email offering etc. If offered at a right price point, we believe this has room to expand the addressable size of the enterprise market.

Jio includes revenues from enterprises in its digital part of the business. The key contributors to the digital revenues include cloud offering, content services, enterprise business and tech services offered to RIL sister companies. While till- date, contribution from the enterprises service (ex- content & inter- company revenues) is small, we expect this business to scale- up in coming years given mgmt focus on this business. RIL in its con- calls has stated that 1) Jio is tapping into new age businesses, like bundled connectivity, security, and Wi- Fi stack. Jio is also growing as an end- to- end managed services partner of enterprises offering; 2) It has been able to increase its wallet share with a lot of large enterprises, especially in the BFSI and the industrial segments; 3) Jio is seeing strong momentum in its IoT portfolio and 4) Apart from BFSI, Jio is working with automotive companies, quick commerce dark stores. Jio has also won some good competitive tenders for government clients. The enterprise cloud has grown well for the company, some of these from government departments.

Bharti's enterprise business could broadly be classified in 5 segments: 1) The core connectivity business. While the margins in this business are good (about reported nos), the market growth is slow at \(4 - 5\%\) yoy; 2) The fast- growing IoT business where Bharti claims to have \(60\%\) market share & strong margins; 3) The commodity wholesale business (messaging & voice) which continues to face headwinds. This is due to shift from SMS to OTT and pricing pressures. Bharti has exited the trading business as margins there are low & under pressure; 4) Security offering is largely through partnerships. As this a wraparound product, both capex & margins are low and 5) The high growth cloud offering, where current enterprise adoption is low. Mgmt is staying away from reselling public cloud as it's a commoditized business & margins are low. Instead, the focus is on private cloud. While this business requires capex, margins are high. The digital segment is growing at c. \(23\%\) yoy for Bharti.

Bharti is also focusing on the software business - like a SaaS business where it can license its software. The development effort for software is happening through its subsidiary Xtelify. This business has high margins with limited capex investment.

Both Bharti & Jio are keen to scale up datacenters and offer Al services both to consumers & enterprises. Given limited visibility of contribution to earnings, we consider this opportunity as an optionality for both Bharti and Jio.

- Al: Building multiple offerings for users & enterprises: With an aim to streamline Al adoption, JPL is developing a comprehensive suite of tools and platforms called JioBrain, a powerful Al service platform that can be offered to enterprises across industries. This is currently used in different parts of Jio operations like network planning and maintenance, resource optimization and customer services. Jio intends to collaborate with its global partners to enable world's lowest Al inferencing cost in India to make Al available for everyone. Jio is also actively partnering with Government of India in its INDIAai mission to build a comprehensive Al ecosystem that democratizes computer access and develops indigenous Al capabilities. Also refer to report: Understanding RIL's collaboration with NVIDIA

- Datacenter: Investments made at RIL level: We note that the current datacenter assets are not a part of Jio but on RIL's balance sheet. RIL has stated its intention to build 2GW of datacenter to capitalize on the Al opportunity in India. Despite the datacenter being part of RIL, we note that Jio could provide a full stack Al solution using GPU as a service. Regional telcos like Indosat and Singtel are providing this with Nvidia collaboration. In our view, the datacenter investments may pick-up from FY27, but capex uptake may be modular. This is because the capacity buildout is expected to be in phases (it takes around 18 months to build a datacenter). With major investments at datacenter expected at Jamnagar, we expect the datacenters to have access to clean energy. This will likely lead to improved energy efficiency and reduction its operating costs given access to stable & predictable energy prices.

- Datacenter: Looking to double capacity: Bharti's datacenter entity Nxtra is one of India's top datacenter operators with c.14 large hyperscale datacenters and \(120+\) edge datacenters across \(65+\) cities. It provides infrastructure for global enterprises, hyperscalers, startups, SMEs and governments. Nxtra intends to invest Rs 450-600 bn over next 3-4 years to double its datacenter capacity to 400 MW, as per media articles. Nxtra is committed to sustainability & net zero carbon emission by 2031 and hence scaling up its renewables' energy capacity.

- Al: Experimenting with multiple offerings: The change what Bharti mgmt has brought is that now Al is at the very heart of its business i.e. placing Al at the very center of all its digital platforms that it has already built and are running at scale. Similar to Jio, Bharti is also building tools and solutions that it needs for its business. On B2B front, Bharti is partnering with Google Cloud and AWS. This allows it to offer cloud services that are designed to support Al workloads as well. Overtime, we expect Al cloud services of Bharti also to pick-up. On B2C front, Bharti's partnership with Perplexity allows its users to have free access to its paid offering "Perplexity Pro" for 1 year.

We consider satellite broadband to be a niche offering in India given higher CPE pricing & already well service broadband need by cellular & fixed networks. We don't expect any threat or benefits from satellite services to existing telcos.

Starlink: Niche offering; pricing high: Bharti & Jio are working with SpaceX to bring Starlink's high- speed internet services to India (commercial details are not known). Currently CPE costs for homes/enterprises are high at c. \(\) 180+\(limiting the affordability. Despite Starlink offering speeds upto 200 - 250 Mbps, over time capacity could be an issue given limited by number of satellites hovering around India. As per media articles, Starlink initial set - up cost is Rs 30K with monthly plans starting at Rs 3.3K. Given expensive price - points (vs cellular & FWA), we expect satellite broadband offering to be a niche offering. Starlink complements existing telco services by extending high - speed internet to the most challenging locations.

Even handset prices are high for direct to cell offering: Starlink also has a Direct- to- Cell network to provide ubiquitous connectivity by eliminating traditional mobile dead zones through satellite- to- mobile technology. There are no changes to hardware, firmware, or special apps required. Compared to terrestrial networks which rely on cell towers, Starlink Direct to Cell uses specially designed satellites that function as cell towers in space to expand terrestrial coverage into otherwise unreached areas. However, this service works on high- end smartphones, limiting the addressable market in price sensitive market like India.

Bharti Group owns stake in OneWeb: In 2021, a consortium of Bharti enterprise (parent- co of listed Bharti Airtel) & UK government aided satellite company OneWeb to come out of bankruptcy by investing \(\) 500\(mn each. In 2023, One Web merged with Eutelsat to create "Eutelsat OneWeb". Bharti enterprise remained the largest shareholder with c. 21.2% stake. In India, OneWeb has an agreement with Hughes to offer its satellite service. In Nov - 23, it became the 1st satellite operator to receive regulatory approval to distribute commercial services in India. OneWeb is positioning itself more as an enterprise and institutional provider vs Starlink which is positioned as a consumer direct model.

Exhibit 24: Starlink satellites with Direct to Cell capability have an advanced eNodeB modem onboard This acts like a cellphone tower in space, allowing network integration similar to a standard roaming partner

- Jio has a partnership with satellite provider SES: In Feb-22, Jio and SES (a Luxembourg-based satellite solutions provider), announced a 51:49 JV under the name of Jio Space Technology Limited. It has received DoT approvals for a 20-year license to set up a mobile satellite network for voice and internet services, becoming \(2^{\text{nd}}\) company in India to receive the DoT nod after OneWeb. The venture aims to use a combination of GEO (Geostationary Satellite Orbit) and MEO (Medium Earth Orbit) satellites. This is different from Starlink and OneWeb's network that operates in the LEO (Low Earth Orbit) orbits. Key difference between two networks is that MEO offers higher latency, but the number of satellites is lower as they are higher up in the orbit.

Our PO of Rs 2,125 for Bharti Airtel is based on an SOTP- based valuation, where we look at the core business and other businesses separately. We analyze the core business (excluding Africa) by using a DCF- based valuation, given the higher visibility of longer- term cash flows. We use a WACC of \(11.2\%\) and terminal growth rate of \(3.5\%\) . We value Bharti's shareholding in Airtel Africa at Rs 89/share based on a DCF model. Our calculated WACC is \(12.3\%\) , based on \(9.0\%\) blended risk- free rate and our terminal growth assumption is \(2.0\%\) . We value Bharti's shareholding in Indus at Rs 80 on a DCF with a WACC of \(10.8\%\) and TGR of \(2.5\%\) , and Bharti ex- Africa, ex- Indus at Rs 2,067. We also use a \(5\%\) hold- co discount.
Upside risks are 1) higher market share gains, 2) improving FCF levels, 3) value unlocking with spin- offs at Payments bank, data- centers
Downside risks are 1) higher competition, 2) higher capex intensity, 3) Tariff hike impact not fully flowing through

Our price objective of Rs 1,660 is based on a SOTP valuation. EV of the O2C & E&P businesses is calculated using EV/EBITDA multiple. We use 7.5X/7X FY26E EV/EBITDA for the 2 businesses respectively. This is at a premium to peer group avg. to factor in integrated nature of business & RIL's scale. We ascribe Rs 176 (9% of EV) to clean energy business, valuing at 2.7X P/IC, discount to P/BV of global clean energy peers. We value its offline retail business at 35X FY26E EV/EBITDA (Rs 560), in- sync with peers average Retail EV/EBITDA and for online business (Rs 106), we use 3X FY26E P/S multiple (in line with global e- com peers). We value Jio telecom entity (Rs 497) at Rs 6.72tn and the ad & commerce potential for Jio digital opportunity (Rs 52) (at 2- year fwd avg P/S multiple for peers). Media business for Disney JV & stakes in media companies is valued at Rs 26/share. The total EV of RIL's business segments, less debt & payables is Rs 1,660/share.

Downside risks: (1) negative cash flow for several years in its diversification (2) aggressive tariff discounts at Jio, (3) lower refining & petrochem margins (4) higher capex/lower growth rates for Retail segment

Upside risks are (1) higher refining & petrochem margins, (2) strong subscriber additions at Jio, (3) strong momentum at online offerings, (4) significant oil/gas discoveries, which are not valued by us
We use DCF- based methodology with WACC of \(10.1\%\) and TGR of \(4\%\) to value the company. At our PO of Rs. 6/share, VIL would trade at FY27E EV/EBITDA multiple of \(12x\) .
Upside risks: 1) Improved traction and market share gains in 4G/5G subs, 2) Better than
expected operational leverage benefits
Downside risks: 1) Further market share losses and 2) Higher than anticipated competition leading to weaker VIL positioning & further pressure on VIL's balance sheet

FUNDAMENTAL EQUITY OPINION KEY: Opinions include a Volatility Risk Rating, an Investment Rating and an Income Rating. VOLATILITY RISK RATINGS, indicators of potential price fluctuation, are: A - Low, B - Medium and C - High. INVESTMENT RATINGS reflect the analyst's assessment of both a stock's absolute total return potential as well as its attractiveness for investment relative to other stocks within its Coverage Cluster (defined below). Our investment ratings are: 1 - Buy stocks are expected to have a total return of at least \(10\%\) and are the most attractive stocks in the coverage cluster; 2 - Neutral stocks are expected to remain flat or increase in value and are less attractive than Buy rated stocks and 3 - Underperform stocks are the least attractive stocks in a coverage cluster. An investment rating of 6 (No Rating) indicates that a stock is no longer trading on the basis of fundamentals. Analysts assign investment ratings considering, among other things, the 0- 12 month total return expectation for a stock and the firm's guidelines for ratings dispersions (shown in the table below). The current price objective for a stock should be referenced to better understand the total return expectation at any given time. The price objective reflects the analyst's view of the potential price appreciation (depreciation).
Investment ratingTotal return expectation (within 12-month period of date of initial rating)Ratings dispersion guidelines for coverage cluster R2Buy≥ 10%≤ 70%Neutral≥ 0%≤ 30%UnderperformN/A≥ 20%
R2Ratings dispersions may vary from time to time where BofA Global Research believes it better reflects the investment prospects of stocks in a Coverage Cluster.

INCOME RATINGS, indicators of potential cash dividends, are: 7 - same/higher (dividend considered to be secure), 8 - same/lower (dividend not considered to be secure) and 9 - pays no cash dividend. Coverage Cluster is comprised of stocks covered by a single analyst or two or more analysts sharing a common industry, sector, region or other classification(s). A stock's coverage cluster is included in the most recent BofA Global Research report referencing the stock.
